properties.name: anchor-name
properties.appliesTo: all elements that generate a principal box

values.name: none
values.prose: The property has no effect.

values.name: <dashed-ident>#
values.prose: If the element generates a principal box, the element is an anchor element, with a list of anchor names as specified. Each anchor name is a tree-scoped name. Otherwise, the property has no effect.

values.name: none
values.prose: No changes in anchor name scope.

values.name: all
values.prose: Specifies that all anchor names defined by this element or its descendants—​whose scope is not already limited by a descendant using anchor-scope—​to be in scope only for this element’s descendants; and limits descendants to only match anchor names to anchor elements within this subtree. This value only affects anchor names in the same tree scope, as if it were a tree-scoped name. (That is, anchor-scope: all acts identically to anchor-scope: --foo, --bar, ..., listing all relevant anchor names.)

values.name: <dashed-ident>
values.prose: Specifies that a matching anchor name defined by this element or its descendants—​whose scope is not already limited by a descendant using anchor-scope—​to be in scope only for this element’s descendants; and limits descendants to only match these anchor names to anchor elements within this subtree. The <dashed-ident> is a tree-scoped name.

values.name: auto
values.prose: Use the implicit anchor element if it exists; otherwise the box has no default anchor element.

values.name: <anchor-name>
values.prose: The target anchor element selected by the specified <anchor-name> is the box’s default anchor element.

properties.name: position-area
properties.appliesTo: positioned boxes with a default anchor box
properties.computedValue: the keyword none or a pair of keywords, see § 3.1.3 Computed Value and Serialization of <position-area>

values.name: none
values.prose: The property has no effect.

values.name: <position-area>
values.prose: If the box does not have a default anchor box, or is not an absolutely positioned box, this value has no effect. Otherwise, selects a region of the position-area grid, and makes that the box’s containing block.

values.name: anchor-center
values.prose: The new anchor-center value makes this case extremely simple: if the positioned box has a default anchor box, then it is centered (insofar as possible) over the default anchor box in the relevant axis.

values.name: anchor-center
values.prose: The new anchor-center value makes this case extremely simple: if the positioned box has a default anchor box, then it is centered (insofar as possible) over the default anchor box in the relevant axis.

values.name: anchor-center
values.prose: The new anchor-center value makes this case extremely simple: if the positioned box has a default anchor box, then it is centered (insofar as possible) over the default anchor box in the relevant axis.

values.name: anchor-center
values.prose: The new anchor-center value makes this case extremely simple: if the positioned box has a default anchor box, then it is centered (insofar as possible) over the default anchor box in the relevant axis.

values.name: always
values.prose: This property has no effect. (The box is displayed without regard for its anchors or its overflowing status.)

values.name: anchors-valid
values.prose: If any of the box’s required anchor references do not resolve to a target anchor element, the box’s visibility property computes to force-hidden. What is a required anchor reference? anchor() functions that don’t have a fallback value; the default anchor *sometimes*? Need more detail here. Any anchors are missing, or all anchors are missing? I can see use-cases for either, potentially. Do we want to make a decision here, or make it controllable somehow?

values.name: anchors-visible
values.prose: If the box has a default anchor box but that anchor box is invisible or clipped by intervening boxes, the box’s visibility property computes to force-hidden.

values.name: no-overflow
values.prose: If the box overflows its inset-modified containing block even after applying position-try, the box’s visibility property computes to force-hidden.

values.name: none
values.prose: The property has no effect; the box’s position options list is empty.

values.name: <dashed-ident>
values.prose: If there is a @position-try rule with the given name, its associated position option is added to the position options list. Otherwise, this value has no effect.

values.name: flip-block
values.prose: swaps the values in the block axis (between, for example, margin-block-start and margin-block-end), essentially mirroring across an inline-axis line.

values.name: flip-inline
values.prose: swaps the values in the inline axis, essentially mirroring across a block-axis line.

values.name: flip-start
values.prose: swaps the values of the start properties with each other, and the end properties with each other (between, for example, margin-block-start and margin-inline-start), essentially mirroring across a diagonal drawn from the start-start corner to the end-end corner.

values.name: <dashed-ident> || <try-tactic>
values.prose: Combines the effects of the previous two options: if there is a @position-try rule with the given name, applies its position option to the base style, then transforms it according to the specified <try-tactic> and adds the result to the box’s position options list. Otherwise, does nothing.

values.name: <'position-area'>
values.prose: Automatically creates a position option composed solely of a position-area property with the given value.

values.name: normal
values.prose: Try the position options in the order specified by position-try-fallbacks.

values.name: most-width
values.prose: For each entry in the position options list, apply that position option to the box, and find the specified inset-modified containing block size that results from those styles. Stably sort the position options list according to this size, with the largest coming first.

values.name: most-height
values.prose: For each entry in the position options list, apply that position option to the box, and find the specified inset-modified containing block size that results from those styles. Stably sort the position options list according to this size, with the largest coming first.

values.name: most-block-size
values.prose: For each entry in the position options list, apply that position option to the box, and find the specified inset-modified containing block size that results from those styles. Stably sort the position options list according to this size, with the largest coming first.

values.name: most-inline-size
values.prose: For each entry in the position options list, apply that position option to the box, and find the specified inset-modified containing block size that results from those styles. Stably sort the position options list according to this size, with the largest coming first.

atrules.name: @position-try
atrules.prose: The @position-try rule defines a position option with a given name, specifying one or more sets of positioning properties that can be applied to a box via position-try-fallbacks,

values.name: <position-area>
values.value: [ [ left | center | right | span-left | span-right | x-start | x-end | span-x-start | span-x-end | x-self-start | x-self-end | span-x-self-start | span-x-self-end | span-all ] || [ top | center | bottom | span-top | span-bottom | y-start | y-end | span-y-start | span-y-end | y-self-start | y-self-end | span-y-self-start | span-y-self-end | span-all ] | [ block-start | center | block-end | span-block-start | span-block-end | span-all ] || [ inline-start | center | inline-end | span-inline-start | span-inline-end | span-all ] | [ self-block-start | center | self-block-end | span-self-block-start | span-self-block-end | span-all ] || [ self-inline-start | center | self-inline-end | span-self-inline-start | span-self-inline-end | span-all ] | [ start | center | end | span-start | span-end | span-all ]{1,2} | [ self-start | center | self-end | span-self-start | span-self-end | span-all ]{1,2} ]

values.name: start
values.prose: The single corresponding row or column, depending on which axis this keyword is specifying. Like in anchor(), the plain logical keywords (start, end, etc) refer to the writing mode of the box’s containing block. The x-start/etc determine their direction in the same way, but in the specified physical axis. The self-* logical keywords (self-start, x-self-end, etc) are identical, but refer to the box’s own writing mode.

values.name: end
values.prose: The single corresponding row or column, depending on which axis this keyword is specifying. Like in anchor(), the plain logical keywords (start, end, etc) refer to the writing mode of the box’s containing block. The x-start/etc determine their direction in the same way, but in the specified physical axis. The self-* logical keywords (self-start, x-self-end, etc) are identical, but refer to the box’s own writing mode.

values.name: span-start
values.prose: Two adjacent rows or columns, depending on which axis this keyword is specifying: the center row/column, and the row/column corresponding to the other half of the keyword as per the single-track keywords. (For example, span-top spans the first two rows—​the center row and the top row.)

values.name: span-end
values.prose: Two adjacent rows or columns, depending on which axis this keyword is specifying: the center row/column, and the row/column corresponding to the other half of the keyword as per the single-track keywords. (For example, span-top spans the first two rows—​the center row and the top row.)

values.name: span-all
values.prose: All three rows or columns, depending on which axis this keyword is specifying.

values.name: anchor()
values.prose: An absolutely positioned box can use the anchor() function as a value in its inset properties to refer to the position of one or more anchor boxes. The anchor() function resolves to a <length>. It is only allowed in the inset properties (and is otherwise invalid).

values.name: <dashed-ident>
values.prose: Specifies the anchor name it will look for. This name is a tree-scoped reference.

values.name: inside
values.prose: Resolves to one of the anchor box’s sides, depending on which inset property it’s used in. inside refers to the same side as the inset property (attaching the positioned box to the "inside" of the anchor box), while outside refers to the opposite.

values.name: outside
values.prose: Resolves to one of the anchor box’s sides, depending on which inset property it’s used in. inside refers to the same side as the inset property (attaching the positioned box to the "inside" of the anchor box), while outside refers to the opposite.

values.name: top
values.prose: Refers to the specified side of the anchor box.

values.name: right
values.prose: Refers to the specified side of the anchor box.

values.name: bottom
values.prose: Refers to the specified side of the anchor box.

values.name: left
values.prose: Refers to the specified side of the anchor box.

values.name: start
values.prose: Refers to one of the sides of the anchor box in the same axis as the inset property it’s used in, by resolving the keyword against the writing mode of either the positioned box (for self-start and self-end) or the positioned box’s containing block (for start and end).

values.name: end
values.prose: Refers to one of the sides of the anchor box in the same axis as the inset property it’s used in, by resolving the keyword against the writing mode of either the positioned box (for self-start and self-end) or the positioned box’s containing block (for start and end).

values.name: self-start
values.prose: Refers to one of the sides of the anchor box in the same axis as the inset property it’s used in, by resolving the keyword against the writing mode of either the positioned box (for self-start and self-end) or the positioned box’s containing block (for start and end).

values.name: self-end
values.prose: Refers to one of the sides of the anchor box in the same axis as the inset property it’s used in, by resolving the keyword against the writing mode of either the positioned box (for self-start and self-end) or the positioned box’s containing block (for start and end).

values.name: <percentage>
values.prose: Refers to a position a corresponding percentage between the start and end sides, with 0% being equivalent to start and 100% being equivalent to end. center is equivalent to 50%.

values.name: center
values.prose: Refers to a position a corresponding percentage between the start and end sides, with 0% being equivalent to start and 100% being equivalent to end. center is equivalent to 50%.

values.name: <anchor-side>
values.value: inside | outside | top | left | right | bottom | start | end | self-start | self-end | <percentage> | center

values.name: anchor-size()
values.prose: An absolutely positioned box can use the anchor-size() function in its sizing properties to refer to the size of one or more anchor boxes. The anchor-size() function resolves to a <length>. It is only allowed in the accepted @position-try properties (and is otherwise invalid).

values.name: width
values.prose: The physical <anchor-size> keywords (width and height) refer to the width and height, respectively, of the target anchor element. Unlike anchor(), there is no restriction on having to match axises; for example, width: anchor-size(--foo height); is valid.

values.name: height
values.prose: The physical <anchor-size> keywords (width and height) refer to the width and height, respectively, of the target anchor element. Unlike anchor(), there is no restriction on having to match axises; for example, width: anchor-size(--foo height); is valid.

values.name: block
values.prose: The logical <anchor-size> keywords (block, inline, self-block, and self-inline) map to one of the physical keywords according to either the writing mode of the box (for self-block and self-inline) or the writing mode of the box’s containing block (for block and inline).

values.name: inline
values.prose: The logical <anchor-size> keywords (block, inline, self-block, and self-inline) map to one of the physical keywords according to either the writing mode of the box (for self-block and self-inline) or the writing mode of the box’s containing block (for block and inline).

values.name: self-block
values.prose: The logical <anchor-size> keywords (block, inline, self-block, and self-inline) map to one of the physical keywords according to either the writing mode of the box (for self-block and self-inline) or the writing mode of the box’s containing block (for block and inline).

values.name: self-inline
values.prose: The logical <anchor-size> keywords (block, inline, self-block, and self-inline) map to one of the physical keywords according to either the writing mode of the box (for self-block and self-inline) or the writing mode of the box’s containing block (for block and inline).

values.name: <anchor-size>
values.value: width | height | block | inline | self-block | self-inline
